title: Chain lube vs chain wax: Pros, cons and which should you choose?
content:
Cyclist
Chain lube vs chain wax: Pros, cons and which should you choose?

There’s a bewildering array of bike chain lubricants available, with each brand touting its unique formulation and the advantages of its particular product.

All are designed to protect your drivetrain from wear, decrease friction and reduce the chances of corrosion, but they differ in how easy they are to apply, the conditions in which they work best and the longevity of protection offered.

The easiest to apply are drip chain lubes, although they may need more frequent cleaning and reapplication and are easily washed off your chain. 

Cooking your chain in a bath of wax may offer increased longevity and lower the tendency to attract dirt, but at the expense of more pre-prep and more bits and bobs. 

Drip wax lubes promise a middle ground, although you still need to be more careful about preparation than with standard lubes.

If it all sounds like too much work, you can always buy a pre-treated chain, though that will still require maintenance eventually.

Read on for our breakdown of the different types of chain lube available, the pros and cons of each and some suggestions of products to try.

Related Posts

Dry lubes

The default way to keep your chain running smoothly is to apply a lubricant. For summer use, a dry lubricant is traditionally the preferred option. Lighter than a wet lube, it consists of a wax lubricant mixed into a solvent carrier fluid. It’s quick to apply and also stays cleaner for longer. Although applied in liquid form, the idea is that the solvent allows it to penetrate your chain links. It then evaporates to leave the ingredients that do the work.

The downside of a dry lube is that it’s easily washed off by wet weather and when you clean your bike, so you need to apply it regularly and it doesn’t pass muster once the weather turns bad.

Dry lube options

White Lightning Clean Ride 

White Lightning’s formulation dries to a waxy finish, which doesn’t tend to attract dirt, making it a good option for dusty conditions. Better yet, when it does get contaminated, it flakes off your chain, lowering the amount of cleaning it needs.

Finish Line Teflon Plus Dry Chain Lube

Almost a default choice for dry weather thanks to its ubiquity, Finish Line’s dry lube is lightweight and stays relatively clean. It’s been reformulated to remove the previous PTFE forever chemical component, replacing it with boron nitride and non-stick ceramics.

Wet lubes

A wet lube is the poor weather alternative to a dry lube. It’s a good option for winter riding and also for gravel bikes that may be ridden somewhere dirty. As an oil, it doesn’t dry out but stays liquid on your chain. 

It will withstand rain and cleaning better than a dry lube, but it’s heavier and will also pick up dirt and become gunky. This means that regular chain cleaning and reapplication are needed to keep your chain running well.

The more viscous consistency than dry lube also means that there may be a bit more friction in your drivetrain – maybe not such a problem for a winter road bike, but not so good if you’re looking for the best possible performance on your race bike or time trial bike.

Wet lube options

Muc-Off C3 Wet Weather Ceramic Lube

Muc-Off says that its Wet Weather Ceramic Lube’s ceramic particles help to protect your chain in wet and muddy conditions. It contains boron nitride to decrease friction and Muc-Off provides a UV torch, which you can shine on your chain to ensure that you’ve got an even coating.

Wolf Tooth WT-1 All Conditions Chain Lube

Although badged all conditions, Wolf Tooth’s lube is a great option for wet rides, Wolf Tooth says that it binds to the metal, increasing durability. We found that it helped to dislodge embedded gunk from our chain, allowing us to just wipe the chain clean and relube, avoiding the need to run it through a chain cleaner. 

  • Read our Wolf Tooth WT-1 All Conditions Chain Lube review 
  • Buy Wolf Tooth WT-1 All Conditions Chain Lube from Tredz (£22)

Immersion wax

Immersion waxing involves melting a pot of wax and placing your chain in it. You can do this in a slow cooker or sealed in a bag and immersed in hot water. 

Stir the chain around then fish it out and hang it over the pot to allow the wax to cool. Finally wipe off the excess, if that’s possible, and break the hardened wax layer between the links. 

The advantage is that the wax will penetrate deep into your chain’s links, lowering friction and the risk of contamination. The wax coating also tends to be durable and less prone to collecting dirt than oil-based lubes. Formulations include low friction lubricant additives such as molybdenum disulphide, tungsten disulphide, graphene, or ‘secret sauce’.

You usually need to start with a new chain and degrease it thoroughly before waxing though, or the wax won’t penetrate and stick to your chain. This adds multiple steps to the process, involves using solvents and may require soaking the chain overnight, although there are more environmentally friendly degreasing options. Some brands advise using an ultrasonic cleaner to help the process, although this may not be essential.

You need to protect yourself from the hot wax too, to avoid burns, so use tongs or another implement to hold the chain and wear insulated gloves and eye protection.

You also need to get your wax to the specified temperature for waxing to be effective, so you may need a thermometer. You’re going to have a pan of wax sitting around, so you need somewhere to keep it out of the way between uses. 

It’s likely that you’ll need to wax your chain periodically, which means removing it from the bike and redipping it. This should help to keep it clean too, so the degreasing that’s needed with a lubed chain is avoided. You’ll probably need to use a new chain quick link each time though.

Immersion wax options

AbsoluteBlack GraphenLube V2

AbsoluteBlack’s patented wax includes graphene as a low friction additive. It claims that it’s less flaky and longer lasting than alternatives, both in the wet and the dry, and stays put even on hot days. 

Each box contains four wax slabs. Although these are black, the chain isn’t coloured after treatment. AbsoluteBlack says that you should get around 480km between waxings on dry roads and that you can top up with its drip wax lube between treatments.

  • Buy AbsoluteBlack GraphenLube V2 from AbsoluteBlack (£30)

Silca Ultimate Chain Waxing System

If you don’t fancy the mess involved in waxing your chain, Silca sells a gadget that could help. It includes a temperature controllable pot to melt your chain wax and get to exactly the temperature you need, plus a hanging mechanism to allow your chain to cool off.

Silca also sells the StripChip, which you can pop in your pot to transform the grease on your chain into a wax helper, which eliminates the degreasing step usually needed before you can wax your chain. You can, of course, buy the wax you need from Silca separately too.

  • Buy the Silca Ultimate Chain Waxing System from Silca (£99)

Drip wax

The alternative to immersion waxing, if you want to go the wax way, is a drip wax. This is generally a water/wax emulsion that allows chain link penetration before it hardens. It’s usually more expensive than oil-based lubes or immersion waxing.

As with immersion waxing, your chain needs to be clean and dry before you start, so it’s best carried out on a new chain before use. The need to degrease your chain makes application a bit more time-consuming than with oil-based lubes. 

You need to ensure that you’ve applied the drip wax to both the inside and outside links of your chain and to the rollers, making application a bit more fiddly than an oil-based lube. The drip wax also usually needs to be allowed to dry overnight before you ride.

The coating may not be as durable as immersion wax, so you may need to reapply the drip wax more often.

Drip wax options

Squirt Long Lasting Chain Lube

Squirt’s formulation is a biodegradable emulsion of waxes in water, so it’s easy to apply to a degreased chain. After application, allow it to dry overnight and Squirt says that it will leave a non-greasy water-repellent film that offers low friction and doesn’t attract dirt or turn gunky.

CeramicSpeed UFO Drip lube

A flashier drip wax option, CeramicSpeed’s UFO wax is available in three discrete formulations: for all conditions, for wet rides and even for indoor use. It claims up to 300km of use per application and that it’s the world’s fastest chain lube.

  • Read our CeramicSpeed UFO Drip Wet Conditions Lube review

Pre-treated chain

The deluxe option is to buy a pre-treated chain. The manufacturer will have taken a standard chain – there are usually options from all the main brands – removed the factory grease and applied its own low friction treatment to the chain.

Brands usually claim ultra-low friction from their pre-treated chains, although they may be prone to contamination or the treatment may wash off in wet or dirty conditions. This may lower the lifetime of the treatment before friction increases, which may already be quite short. You can usually retreat the chain with the brand’s drip lube to restore the low friction qualities though.

Expensive, a pre-treated chain does give you a low friction coating without the faff of degreasing and waxing.

Pre-waxed chain options

CeramicSpeed UFO Chain

The CeramicSpeed UFO chain comes pre-treated and ready to install. CeramicSpeed says that the chain can save between 2 and 5 watts over a standard chain. Its treatment should last for up to 650km, before you need to reapply its UFO Drip Wax. It’s designed for dry conditions though, so may not stand up to wet or muddy rides.

  • Buy the CeramicSpeed UFO chain from Merlin Cycles (from £115) 

Silca Pre-Waxed Race Chain

Another go-faster option from Silca, it claims that its Pre-Waxed Race Chain is up to 20% faster than alternatives. It also says that it should last for up to 500km, with regular maintenance and retreatment with its Super Secret Chain Coating every 160km.

  • Buy the Silca Pre-Waxed Race chain from Silca (from £99)

Now read our guide to how to choose a replacement chain.

author: pnorman
